oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Lionel Cartwright - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Lionel Cartwright (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Lionel Cartwright; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie and Lionel Cartwright joke about his album title and Cartwright confirms his real name -- (00:23) Cartwright describes "Fallin' Again" as a minor key song in an up-tempo influenced by the Everly Brothers -- (00:53) Cartwright talks about "Like Father Like Son" and being at the Blue Bird Cafe and hearing it first performed by Don Schlitz -- (02:58) Collie and Cartwright talk about "You're Gonna Make Her Mine" being a personal ode from Cartwright -- (03:46) Cartwright talks about Doc Watson's influence on "A Little Lesser Blue" and how he doesn't do it live -- (04:32) Cartwright opens up to Collie about his first album and the long recording time required to find his variety -- (05:50) Cartwright talks about the group the stuck around him through the growth process (06:24) Cartwright discusses his new single "In My Eyes" and the influences of being on the road for work -- (07:03) Cartwright talks about growing up in Gallipolis, Ohio and moving to West Virginia to discover country music -- (08:00) Cartwright talks about the variety of artists he enjoys and being a self-taught musician playing his brother uke -- (09:03) Cartwright tells about the first time he heard country music -- (09:23) Cartwright talks about listening to WWVA and hiding a radio in his room -- (10:08) Cartwright talks about arriving in Nashville and auditioning for the I-40 Paradise -- (11:13) Cartwright talks with Collie about musical heritage in Knoxville and meeting his wife / Felice and Boudleaux Bryant -- (12:26) Collie and Cartwright converse about the Bryant's 1400 recorded tracks and what it was like to work with them -- (14:02) Collie gives the advice to find professionals to work with -- (14:25) Cartwright talks about the Bryant's influence -- (14:48) Cartwright discusses the commute and moving back to Nashville in 1986 after getting signed to MCA -- (15:45) "Give Me His Last Chance" is discussed by Cartwright as his inspiration coming through as he was down at a loading dock on Percy Priest lake -- (17:08) Collie and Cartwright talk about "That's Why They Call It Falling" and the unpredictability of falling in love -- (18:12) Cartwright's "Blue Fiddle Waltz" was inspired from a fiddler contest and an older gentlemen that blew everyone away -- (19:30) "She Never Saw Love" is described as a caring and unselfish song by Cartwright -- (20:41) "Let the Hard Times Roll" is the last tune that Cartwright uses in shows and he describes it as the hard times coming and going -- (21:30) Cartwright talks about not having a plan b after music and being a fan of the industry -- (22:12) Collie jokes about stealing money -- (22:28) Collie and Cartwright interview about a list of Cartwright's music favorite -- (23:09) Collie asks Cartwright about his love life and Cartwright talks about teaching his wife to ice skate -- (23:44) Collie and Cartwright say goodbye and thank each other
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Cartwright, Lionel; Collie, Biff;
